information.title: Definition
information.description: Reservation in India is a system of affirmative action that provides representation for historically disadvantaged groups in education, employment, and politics.

information.title: Constitutional Basis
information.description: Articles 15 and 16 of the Indian Constitution provide for reservation for Scheduled Castes (SCs), Scheduled Tribes (STs), and Other Backward Classes (OBCs) in public employment and education.

information.title: Categories
information.description: The main categories for reservation are Scheduled Castes (SCs), Scheduled Tribes (STs), and Other Backward Classes (OBCs). Some states also have reservations for Economically Weaker Sections (EWS).

information.title: Percentage of Reservation
information.description: The Supreme Court has capped the reservation at 50% in most cases. However, some states have exceeded this limit. The current reservation stands at 15% for SCs, 7.5% for STs, and 27% for OBCs in central government jobs and educational institutions.

information.title: Creamy Layer
information.description: The concept of 'creamy layer' applies to OBCs, excluding the advanced sections of these communities from the benefits of reservation. This is determined based on income and other socio-economic factors.

information.title: Women's Reservation
information.description: There is 33% reservation for women in local bodies (Panchayats and Municipalities). A bill for 33% reservation for women in Parliament and state legislatures is pending.
